name: aws-workbench
description: Your complete AWS toolkit, right in VS Code

commands.title: Aws Access:Test Aws Connectivity With Active User
Aws Access:Copy Credentials To Default Profile

view/item/context.when: view == AwsWorkbenchTree && (viewItem == Queue || viewItem == Queue || viewItem == PublishAdhoc || viewItem == PublishFile)
view == AwsWorkbenchTree && (viewItem == Topic || viewItem == Topic || viewItem == PublishAdhoc || viewItem == PublishFile)

view == AwsWorkbenchTree && (viewItem == StepFunc || viewItem == TriggerConfig || viewItem == TriggerSavedPayload || viewItem == TriggerWithPayload || viewItem == TriggerFilePayload || viewItem == TriggerNoPayload)

view == AwsWorkbenchTree && (viewItem == Lambda || viewItem == TriggerConfig || viewItem == TriggerSavedPayload || viewItem == TriggerWithPayload || viewItem == TriggerFilePayload || viewItem == TriggerNoPayload)

viewsWelcome.contents:
Welcome to AWS Workbench! 
 Click the [+] button in the title bar to add AWS resources like S3 buckets, Lambda functions, etc. 

 To Access AWS, you need to configure AWS credentials. 
 [Configure Credentials](command:aws-access-vscode-extension.ListAwsProfiles)

scripts.pretest: npm run compile && npm run lint
